caseTitle: A CRITIQUE OF SOME ASPECTS OF THE INSURANCE LAW, 1989 (PNDCL
summary: This legal commentary critiques key provisions of Ghana's Insurance Law, 1989 (PNDCL 227), focusing on its reform of common law principles in insurance. The author commends Section 52(1) for deeming insurance agents who complete proposal forms as agents of the insurer, thereby overturning the precedent in Newsholme Brothers v Road Transport and General Insurance Co Ltd, which disadvantaged insured parties, particularly the illiterate. However, the author strongly criticizes Sections 57 and 58. Section 57(1) is faulted for assuming the duty of disclosure rests solely with the insured and for creating ambiguity about the form of questioning. Section 57(2) is criticized for introducing a subjective test of intent that will lead to litigation. Section 58's adoption of a 'reasonable person' test for materiality is rejected in favor of the established 'prudent insurer' test, as it is deemed impractical for laypersons to assess materiality in complex insurance contexts. Finally, Section 59 is welcomed for limiting the harsh effects of 'basis of the contract' clauses and for restricting insurers' ability to avoid policies for immaterial breaches of warranty or condition.
verdict: The commentary concludes that while some reforms in PNDCL 227 are beneficial, others—particularly in Sections 57 and 58—introduce significant legal uncertainty and practical difficulties that may ultimately harm the insured and increase litigation.
winningSide: Insured (in principle, for Section 52 and 59); however, overall legislative framework is seen as flawed and potentially detrimental due to ambiguous provisions.
citations: Newsholme Brothers v Road Transport and General Insurance Co Ltd
Guardian Assurance Co Ltd v Khayat Trading Store
Bawden v London, Edinburgh and Glasgow Assurance Co
Re Bradley and Essex and Suffolk Accident Indemnity Society
Banque Keyser Ullman S A v Skandia Insurance Co
CTI v Oceanus Mutual Underwriting Association (Bermuda)
rationaleHighlights: Section 52(1) deems insurance agents completing proposal forms as agents of the insurer, overturning Newsholme Brothers.
Section 57(1) limits disclosure duty to questions asked, but creates ambiguity in application.
Section 57(2) introduces subjective intent in non-disclosure, risking litigation.
Section 58 replaces 'prudent insurer' with 'reasonable person' test for materiality, criticized as impractical.
Section 59 restricts 'basis of contract' clauses and limits avoidance for immaterial breaches of warranty.
